meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

I'm diving into the world of wrestling games with AEW: Fight Forever. As a seasonal grok video game reviewer, I'm always on the lookout for a good time, and this one's got potential – but is it enough to knock it out of the ring?

First off, let me say that the IGN critic was spot on when they said "unrealized potential." AEW: Fight Forever feels like a great start, with bouncy animations and fast-paced action. But, boy, those bugs and opaque systems are gonna keep you from getting too excited. The single-player mode is also poorly written – it's all about the branching options, but good luck finding 'em!

Game Informer got close to the mark when they said this game has "potential." Yeah, it does! The arcade-style gameplay is a blast, and I'm all for some 90s and early 2000s nostalgia. However, that potential's gotta be nurtured – until then, even die-hard AEW fans might find themselves stuck on the sidelines.

Now, Slant Magazine saw things differently. They loved how Yuke's kept the game accessible while still bringing out the unique pulse-raising and hard-hitting moments from an AEW show. I get it – this game is all about that balance. But what about those bugs, huh?

Gaming Age gave me a chuckle with their "chaotic blast" description. That sums up my experience perfectly! Exciting gameplay and ease of play mean I'll be replaying it for a while. And hey, DLC could help with that roster limitation – but let's not get too ahead of ourselves.

SpazioGames took things down a notch by saying this game lacks the improvements added to previous games. Yeah, it does feel like a step back in terms of content and gameplay. But hey, there's still something to be said for those arcade-style vibes.

Last but not least, COGconnected brought the hype with their "best wrestling game since WWF No Mercy" claim. I mean, I'm all for over-the-top gimmick matches and silly mini-games! The visceral nature of every punch and slam gets me pumped – almost makes me want to join AEW (almost).

God is a Geek chimed in with their take on the career mode, saying it's inspired by Yakuza. Now that sounds like fun! Matches are a blast to play, and that career mode has some serious potential.

So what's the verdict? Well, I'm still figuring that out – but one thing's for sure: AEW: Fight Forever's got heart. It might not be perfect, but it's an arcade-style wrestling game that's all about having a good time. And hey, who doesn't love a good underdog story?

Stay tuned for more seasonal grok reviews!
